item.title: A Fresh Archlinux Installation
item.description: I am currently waiting for my new machine, which I ordered 2 weeks ago. After a lot of research and evaluation, I finally decided to pick the Lenovo T490s. I actually wanted the X1 Carbon, but I was unable to order this machine here in Austria (for whatever reason). Nevertheless, the T490s is pretty close to the X1, and delivers a decent platform for my new Archlinux installation. While I am waiting for the delivery (expected date end of next week), I am mentally prepare myself with a new and fresh Arch installation.

item.title: COVID-19 and the effect on how we work
item.description: We are in week two of the corona pandemic. The last 8 days changed completely how we work and collaborate. We closed our office at Robotic Eyes and all employees had to work from home. As a software company, we are in a good position to switch from on-site collocated style to a complete remote development firm. One of the major challenges - except the business impact and consequences - is to keep up the communication and to organize the team.

item.title: Enable tcp access for docker
item.description: On my Arch system, docker does not expose the tcp port by default, therefore I get the following error: Warning: failed to get default registry endpoint from daemon (Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at tcp://192.168.0.16:2375. Is the docker daemon running?). Using system default: https://index.docker.io/v1/ Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at tcp://192.168.0.16:2375. Is the docker daemon running? It took me quite some time to get the root cause of the problem.

item.title: How suckless changes my life
item.description: In the last years, I tried get more efficient by removing bloated software on my machine. Some of you may know that I am running Arch Linux, which builds the basis for my daily activities. On top of it, the terminal is my main working area. Last year I switched from traditional window managers to the tiling window manager dwm. Tiling window managers have the advantage that your screen is not messed up with floating windows which need to be moved, resized using the mouse.

item.title: The Go language
item.description: I recently discovered the “new” programming language Go and really got my attention. Go was announced in November 2009 and the first version (v1.0) was released in March 2012.
